page.title: 15ELMBRIDGE - CONSERVATION
page.content: As roadsides are not now sprayed with herbicides and are cut only one swathe width after seeding some wild flowers ie poppy, chamomile, bluebell, and campion are now re-colonising road verges. Rarer protected wild flowers, ie cowslips, are carefully conserved by individual landowners. Several varieties of trees, including conifers and native hardwoods are being planted both as individual specimens and in existing woodland. Small areas of new woodland are being created by private householders. Ponds are being cleaned and reinstated to encourage waterloving plants and birds. Streams are kept clear but the water can be polluted by organic loading from land drainage. Some public footpaths in the area are well used, others less so as they are neither signposted nor waymarked.
